awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Impact of Local and National Government Narratives on Renewable Energy Transitions
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation research improvement project will examine the local and national narratives on large-scale renewable energy projects and their impacts for rural communities’ natural resources and wellbeing. This project will improve understanding of the national-level dynamics of renewable energy development, of the factors that determine justification for large-scale projects, and of best practices regarding local community involvement in such projects. Findings will be broadly disseminated through peer-reviewed journal articles, conference presentations, and policy briefs and papers, with implications on environmental sustainability and human health and wellbeing. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career. 

This project will examine how local and national government narratives influence the development of largescale renewable energy projects. The project will explore how national government dynamics influence the type of renewable energy projects that are selected, where such projects are implemented, who implements them, and how they impact local communities. Data collection will be carried out using the following methods: archival research to collect policy and technical documents, media reports; participant observation at meetings on renewable energy; social network mapping of and semi-structured interviews with actors involved in renewable energy transitions. The theories and methodologies developed in this research will provide new insights and approaches to research involving governments and communities that are pursuing transitions to renewable energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined the development of renewable energy in Senegal. Specifically, it sought to better understand the discourses that rationalize and justify the country's renewable energy development strategy (focusing on utility-scale projects), as well as the impacts of such projects on surrounding communities. It did so by drawing on theoretical approaches rooted in political ecology, critical development studies, and critical agrarian studies, and by using primarily qualitative data collection methodologies including document collection and analysis, participant observation, and semi-structured interviews at the national and sub-national (local government and community) level.

The project's findings shed light on the ownership and financial structures of utility-scale renewable energy projects in Senegal, which, while underpinned by narratives of development, climate change mitigation, and energy access expansion at the national level, are very much influenced by multi-scalar interactions between transnational capital flows, long-present but also new development institutions and private developers, and the material demands of both renewable energy technologies and the territories in which they are installed. The findings point out the contextual particularities that are important in determining how Senegal specifically has approached renewable energy development, but also highlight some potential similarities that other countries in the global South may face.

At the community level, the project examined the perceptions of community leaders and community members of the Parc Eolien Taiba NDiaye, a newly installed 158-megawatt wind power project in a rural municipality just northeast of the capital city Dakar. This work revealed that overall, while community members highlighted i) the importance of shifting to renewable energy sources for climate change mitigation purposes and reducing environmental pollution, and ii) that this particular project did better than other nearby projects (e.g. phosphate mining or oil-fueled power plants) with regards to consultation and (lack of) adverse health impacts, they called for improvements in how the project carried out consultation and compensation. Specifically, the change in ownership of the project in 2016 brought about a shift in the way in which consultations with communities were held, shifting community members' experiences with the project. In addition, due to land being state-owned and leased by the operating company of the wind farm, many community members who lost land to the project felt that they simply had no choice or power in influencing the land acquisition process, although there existed generational and gendered variations in these perceptions.

Thus far, the Co-PI published this project's findings in Environment and Planning E: Nature and Space in September 2021, under the title "In pursuit of diverse energy futures: the political economy of electricity in Senegal". The Co-PI has also presented this work at conferences such as the American Association of Geographers (AAG) annual meetings (2019, 2021), and the Society for Advancement of Socio-Economics (SASE) (2021). Project findings will also be shared with project participants in the form of at least two additional planned papers, briefs, and presentations. The Co-PI continues to be in communication with project participants both in Washington, D.C. and in Senegal, and plans to extend this research as Senegal continues its development of renewable energy.
